channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Louisiana's top health official, a critic of the COVID vaccine, will be CDC deputy
item.description: Louisiana's surgeon general Dr. Ralph Abraham, who has praised Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s tenure as health secretary and called COVID vaccines "dangerous," will become the second-highest ranking official at the CDC.
item.content:encoded:
Louisiana's surgeon general Dr. Ralph Abraham, who has praised Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s tenure as health secretary and called COVID vaccines "dangerous," will become the second-highest ranking official at the CDC.

(Image credit: Gerald Herbert)
item.dc:creator: Rosemary Westwood

item.title: New limits for rent algorithm that prosecutors say let landlords drive up prices
item.description: Landlords could no longer rely on rent-pricing software to quietly track each other's moves and push rents higher using confidential data, under a settlement between RealPage Inc. and federal prosecutors.
item.content:encoded:
Landlords could no longer rely on rent-pricing software to quietly track each other's moves and push rents higher using confidential data, under a settlement between RealPage Inc. and federal prosecutors.

(Image credit: Mark Schiefelbein)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: How a 'sweet and shy' tortoise outlived empires and survived two world wars
item.description: No one knows exactly when Gramma was born. But if the estimated birth year of 1884 is accurate, Chester Arthur occupied the Oval Office and there were only 39 states at the time.
item.content:encoded:
No one knows exactly when Gramma was born. But if the estimated birth year of 1884 is accurate, Chester Arthur occupied the Oval Office and there were only 39 states at the time.

(Image credit: San Diego Zoo/YouTube)
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: Sen. Mark Kelly: Trump and Hegseth don't 'understand the Constitution'
item.description: Sen. Mark Kelly, D-Ariz., and other congressional Democrats released a video last week letting service members know they can refuse illegal orders. Kelly is now being investigated for misconduct.
item.content:encoded:
Sen. Mark Kelly, D-Ariz., and other congressional Democrats released a video last week letting service members know they can refuse illegal orders. Kelly is now being investigated for misconduct.

(Image credit: Zayrha Rodriguez)
item.dc:creator: Scott Detrow

item.title: When private equity invests in youth sports facilities
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Luke Goldstein of The Lever, who wrote about the rise of private equity control of youth hockey facilities.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Luke Goldstein of The Lever, who wrote about the rise of private equity control of youth hockey facilities.
item.dc:creator: Juana Summers

item.title: The case against Comey failed because of Trump's prosecutor. Who is she?
item.description: A federal judge dismissed the Justice Department's cases against James Comey and Letitia James, saying the prosecutor who led them was unlawfully appointed. Here's what to know about her.
item.content:encoded:
A federal judge dismissed the Justice Department's cases against James Comey and Letitia James, saying the prosecutor who led them was unlawfully appointed. Here's what to know about her.

(Image credit: Jacquelyn Martin)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: A former U.S. attorney offers 'A Manual for Keeping a Democracy'
item.description: Joyce Vance, author of Giving Up Is Unforgivable, discusses recent impactful decisions by courts and the Justice Department, and how her son helped her understand Gen Z's view of defending democracy.
item.content:encoded: Joyce Vance, author of Giving Up Is Unforgivable, discusses recent impactful decisions by courts and the Justice Department, and how her son helped her understand Gen Z's view of defending democracy.
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: Syrians displaced by war are returning to find homes occupied by foreign fighters
item.description: Fighters have settled across northern Syria, surprising displaced Syrians who've tried to return to their homes. Nearly a year after the war's end, sorting out property ownership remains a pressing issue.
item.content:encoded:
Fighters have settled across northern Syria, surprising displaced Syrians who've tried to return to their homes. Nearly a year after the war's end, sorting out property ownership remains a pressing issue.

(Image credit: Emily Feng)
item.dc:creator: Emily Feng

item.title: Democrats plan a new investment in winning rural voters, who've fled the party
item.description: Democrats are announcing a new investment to win over voters in rural areas — where the party has suffered deep losses in recent elections — by leaning on an economic message.
item.content:encoded:
Democrats are announcing a new investment to win over voters in rural areas — where the party has suffered deep losses in recent elections — by leaning on an economic message.

(Image credit: Charlie Riedel)
item.dc:creator: Ashley Lopez

item.title: U.S. plans to cut ties with Boy Scouts. And, Comey and James' criminal cases dismissed
item.description: Documents show the U.S. Military plans to cut support to the Boy Scouts. And, a judge dismissed the indictments against former FBI Director James Comey and N.Y. Attorney General Letitia James.
item.content:encoded:
Documents show the U.S. Military plans to cut support to the Boy Scouts. And, a judge dismissed the indictments against former FBI Director James Comey and N.Y. Attorney General Letitia James.

(Image credit: Dia Dipasupil)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton
